description: Repeated successful logins for user 'samantha.thornton' within the same second could indicate automated use of stolen credentials.
Duplicate login success using the same account from the same IP, indicating possible scripted credential use.
Yet another successful authentication log from the same IP and user suggests automated access or credential stuffing.
Login from same IP and username using IMAP, possible indication of scripted credential reuse.
Redundant login success logs with identical credentials and timestamp are indicative of a possible automated login process.
New login success at the next second but same IP and user; continued automated activity is suspected.
Repeat of the same session ID and credentials suggests multiple logs of the same event or repeated login attempts.
Another duplicate of the previous successful login, reinforcing suspicion of scripted or batch login attempts.
Routine ClamAV signature update; a normal scheduled operation with no signs of malicious activity.
Successful login for another user (damian.jordan), using same PLAIN method and IMAP access; could be part of the same campaign.
Authentication success for user 'damian.jordan' using IMAP with repeated logins indicates use of valid credentials; may be indicative of account compromise.
Multiple successful logins from the same IP using the same credentials suggest possible automated access using valid credentials.
Successful repeated logins on multiple logs imply persistent access by a threat actor using valid credentials.
Login success for the same user and IP across log files; potentially a single access event logged by multiple systems or repeated access.
Redundant successful login with same session and credentials as previous; corroborates multiple log collectors observing same session.
Same session ID logged again suggests multiple collectors logging the same successful authentication event.
Another log repetition of the same IMAP login, likely a result of log redundancy, not a new or unique event.
Log duplication of session event previously recorded; not indicative of further activity.
New session login one second later with same credentials and source IP implies ongoing access, consistent with account compromise.
Same as previous, recorded in different log path; duplicate confirmation of ongoing use of valid account.
Dovecot login successful for user damian.jordan from internal IP. May indicate use of valid credentials for access.
SSH login success for user phopkins using public key from a different IP. Suggests remote access using valid credentials.
PAM login session opened for user phopkins by root UID. Indicates elevation or system-level session access.
Systemd confirms user phopkins session opened by UID 0 (root). Supports successful authentication and session start.
Session closed for user phopkins. This indicates normal session termination, no suspicious behavior by itself.
SSH session for user phopkins closed, matching expected session lifecycle. No malicious indication.
Suricata IDS alert for APT user-agent fetching Ubuntu package via HTTP. Likely a normal system update.
Snort alert matching Suricata on APT traffic from 192.168.128.4 to archive.ubuntu.com. Not suspicious.
APT User-Agent alert on 10.35.33.111 traffic to Ubuntu mirror. Mirrors routine update activity.
Suricata alert confirms same APT-based behavior from 10.35.33.111 as previous entry. Normal update behavior.
APT user-agent indicating package manager update (Ubuntu apt), typically benign but flagged due to policy.
Duplicate log of APT package manager access using user-agent string flagged by IDS.
Outbound Debian APT request from another client IP; still consistent with normal update behavior.
Snort alert for outbound APT activity using known user-agent, not indicative of malicious behavior.
Another apt package fetch for libxml2; normal behavior unless performed unexpectedly by unauthorized system.
Snort alert duplicating Suricata's detection of Ubuntu package download.
APT package installation activity flagged due to policy but no evidence of malicious behavior.
Duplicate log of previous APT traffic from another client IP; likely normal update cycle.
Dovecot IMAP login detected as successful; could be benign or indicate use of stolen credentials.
Repeated successful authentication, may indicate persistence mechanism using valid credentials.
Successful IMAP login detected for user 'samantha.thornton'; frequent logins (firedtimes=48) may indicate valid credential usage, possibly by an attacker.

AppArmor profile replacement for '/usr/lib/NetworkManager/nm-dhcp-client.action' using 'apparmor_parser'; may indicate a legitimate system update or attempted evasion via security policy manipulation.
AppArmor profile replacement for 'nm-dhcp-helper' using root privileges; similar behavior repeated multiple times, typical of legitimate configuration or provisioning tasks.
Another AppArmor profile change to '/sbin/dhclient'; pattern consistent with configuration updates, though frequent changes could mask malicious behavior.
AppArmor profile replacement for 'connman dhclient-script'; while potentially benign, repeated system-level changes may warrant review.
SSH public key authentication successful for user 'phopkins' from internal IP; behavior could indicate lateral movement or initial access using a valid account.
Session opened for user 'phopkins' via PAM with root UID context; indicates session escalation or a privileged user login.
Systemd-user session initiated for 'phopkins' by root; similar to previous PAM alert, consistent with login session progression.
First-time sudo use by user 'phopkins' to view '/var/log/syslog'; possible reconnaissance or system information gathering by a newly privileged user.
Log file access with elevated privileges may indicate an attempt to gather sensitive information or further credentials.
Log entry indicates a PAM login session closure for user root, which is a routine system event with no indicators of malicious behavior.
APT package manager outbound HTTP request to ppa.launchpad.net, flagged due to policy signature; routine update behavior in Linux environments.
Duplicate detection of APT outbound HTTP connection in Snort format; redundant information indicating benign system update activity.
APT outbound traffic to security.ubuntu.com triggered policy signature; common behavior for security updates on Ubuntu systems.
Duplicate Snort-style alert for APT update request; confirms previously seen benign update traffic.
APT User-Agent outbound from different host (10.35.33.111) to ppa.launchpad.net; also part of normal system maintenance/update behavior.
Snort duplicate of APT HTTP request from same host as above; expected and benign.
Snort alert for APT HTTP update request to security.ubuntu.com; legitimate system process flagged due to strict IDS policy.
Suricata alert for same APT update from above line; confirms benign traffic from package manager.
APT package manager request to archive.ubuntu.com marked by IDS policy rule; system update process without signs of malicious activity.
APT traffic using HTTP protocol detected; matches signature for outbound package management tools.
System contacting archive.ubuntu.com using Debian APT-HTTP; normal behavior for updates.
Snort alert indicating outbound APT HTTP request; part of routine OS update.
APT HTTP request to archive.ubuntu.com for bionic-updates; normal package update behavior.
Snort log of APT outbound request to HTTP server (Ubuntu updates).
APT HTTP request to archive.ubuntu.com for bionic-updates, part of software management routine.
Multiple IDS alerts fired for the same signature within a short window; likely benign but flagged for frequency.
APT request for bionic-backports using HTTP detected by Suricata; standard OS update behavior.
Snort record of Debian APT update over HTTP; consistent with system maintenance tasks.
APT access to bionic-backports repo using HTTP; flagged by Suricata policy rule, but appears benign.
Outbound APT user-agent traffic likely related to legitimate system updates using package manager; matches known signature but not suspicious.
APT User-Agent making HTTP request to Ubuntu security repo; expected for system updates, matching policy rule.
APT user-agent HTTP traffic to known Ubuntu repository; system update in progress.
Outbound package update traffic flagged by Snort; routine behavior for Linux systems.
APT user-agent traffic making requests to Ubuntu mirror; not indicative of malicious behavior.
User 'phopkins' successfully executed a command as root using sudo; indicates privilege escalation via sudo.
Login session closed for root via sudo; benign end of privileged session.
Valid sudo session opened by user 'phopkins' for root access; shows use of valid credentials for privilege escalation.
User 'meghan.morris' logged into mail server using Dovecot IMAP; behavior consistent with standard authentication.
Successful login for 'meghan.morris' via IMAP; repeated similar to previous indicating a valid session continuation.
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful IMAP login using valid account 'meghan.morris' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81
Successful login to dovecot IMAP service using valid user credentials 'daniel.morgan' via PLAIN authentication method, from IP 172.17.131.81, over TLS.
Repeated successful login event for user 'daniel.morgan' using PLAIN method over TLS from same IP, indicating normal or repeated valid authentication.
Same successful authentication event as above, from same user and IP, logged in a different file location. Consistent with valid login activity.
Duplicate successful login events from same user and IP, consistent with normal use or monitoring artifacts.
Repeated successful logins by 'daniel.morgan' using PLAIN authentication over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81, indicating valid credentials in use.
Consistent with other successful login events by the same user from same IP and session type, indicating valid authentication activity.
Successful login for user 'daniel.morgan' from IP 172.17.131.81 via PLAIN method over TLS, continuing the pattern of valid authenticated access.
Repeated successful authentication of user 'daniel.morgan' using PLAIN over TLS, from same IP, suggesting valid usage rather than suspicious activity.
Same user logging in successfully with valid credentials from same source IP, consistent with authorized user activity.
Multiple successful logins of user 'daniel.morgan' via PLAIN method over TLS from IP 172.17.131.81, indicating continuous authorized access.
